items.item_details:
Item:  9.01
	 
TO:
Board of Trustees
				 
				 
FROM:  
Dan Moser, Superintendent 
				 
				 
PREPARED BY:
Juan Cruz, Assistant Superintendent of Instructional Services, and Kirsten King, Director of Instructional Services
				 
				 
SUBJECT:
Hold Public Hearing at Approximately 6:05 p.m. on a Charter School Petition Renewal Submitted by San Jose Conservation Corps
	 
BACKGROUND
	 
Public Charter Schools are approved initially for up to a five (5) year period and at the end of that time must apply for a charter school renewal for a term of five (5) years and continue to apply for renewal after each five (5) year term. Pursuant to Education Code 47605 a public hearing is required within thirty (30) days following the submission of a renewal charter school petition to the district.  The renewal petition was submitted to the district on April 19, 2012.
	 
During the Public Hearing the Governing Board of the school district shall consider the level of support for the petition by the teachers employed by the district, other employees of the district and parents.  The Governing Board shall either grant or deny the charter renewal within sixty (60) days of receipt of the petition; however, the date may be extended by an additional thirty (30) days if both parties agree to the extension.  Such agreement has been reached and at the June 7, 2012 Board Meeting the Governing Board shall make its determination.
	 
	 
FUNDING SOURCE: 
Part of Review Process
	 
FISCAL IMPACT: 
Part of Review Process
	 
	 
RECOMMENDATION:
Hold Public Hearing to consider level of support for the petition renewal submitted by San Jose Conservation Corps.

items.item_details:
EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
	 
Item:  11.03
	 
	 
TO:
Board of Trustees
				 
				 
FROM:  
Dan Moser, Superintendent
				 
				 
SUBJECT:
Discussion, Consideration and/or Action regarding Selection/Appointment of Measure G and Measure E Citizens' Bond Oversight Committee Members
	 
	 
Since the CBOC appointment of 14 members on April 21, 2011, three returning members and four other randomly selected members were chosen for a one-year term.  This division of CBOC members put into place a yearly rotation of CBOC members.  The rotation process allows for history and consistency on the CBOC. Under the by-laws of the CBOC 3 returning members termed out.  Additionally, the CBOC member representing senior citizens resigned due to meeting conflicts.  This resulted in a total of 8 seats to fill for the CBOC.  
Thanks to the following CBOC Members for their service to the Voters of the East Side Community:
Bill Bascom
John Delgado
Sherry Gilmore
David Hernandez
Elizabeth Martinez
John Moore
Andres Quintero
Jon Reinke 
For this year’s selection process, advertisements were announced in the newspaper, schools, district office and district’s website.  Administration considered 11 qualified applications (including 3 returning applications) for the eight seats.  The CBOC is required to have a least seven members that meet the criteria listed below.  
One (1) member shall be active in a business organization representing the business community located within the district.
One (1) member shall be active in a senior citizens’ organization.
One (1) member shall be active in a bona fide taxpayers’ organization.
One (1) member shall be the parent or guardian of a child enrolled in the district.
One (1) member shall be both a parent or guardian of a child enrolled in the district and be active in a parent-teacher organization, such as the Parent Teacher Association or the School Site Council.
Two (2) members of the community at-large.
	 
No employees or officials of the District can be appointed to the CBOC.  Also vendors, contractors, or consultants of the District are not allowed to serve as members of the Committee.
	 
Additionally, the outgoing CBOC of March 2011, recommended that the Board increase parent representation on the Committee.
	 
The new CBOC membership will be comprised of: 6 members who currently are serving terms until May 2013 plus 8 newly appointed to fill  the areas listed below: 
Active in a business organization – Rebecca Gallardo (new member)
Active in a senior citizens’ organization –  Ramon Martinez (new one year member filling the term of member who resigned )
Active in a bona fide taxpayer’s organization – Andres Quintero (returning 2nd term member)  
Parent / guardian of a child in the district – Cecil Lawson (AH) 
Parent / guardian of a child in the district and active in a parent-teacher organization – Derek Grasty (EV)
Members of the community at large – (at least 2 are required)
Julio Saucedo (AH), 
Martin Reinders (ST)
Rao Tallapragada (EV)
Tim Tom 
Joshua Barousse (new member)
John Delgado (ST) (returning 2nd term member)
Brad Geldert (MP) (new member)
Sherry Gilmore (SC) (2nd term) (returning 2nd term member)
Vince Tran (PH) (new member)
	 
The administration would like to thank the following community members for their interest and willingness to serve on the CBOC.
Sharon Bennett
Leo Cortez
William Murphy
	 
	 
FISCAL IMPACT:
Not Applicable
	 
FUNDING SOURCE:
Not Applicable
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees appoint the persons to serve on the Measure G and Measure E Citizens' Bond Oversight Committee as recommended by Administration.

Item:  11.04
	 
	 
TO:
Board of Trustees
				 
				 
FROM:  
Lan Nguyen, Board Audit Committee Chair, and Patricia Martinez-Roach, Board Audit Committee Vice Chair
				 
				 
SUBJECT:
Discussion, Consideration and/or Action regarding Selection/Appointment of Alternate 
Board Audit Committee Members
	 
	 
	 
At the January 21, 2010, Board Meeting a staggered process for the selection of Board Audit Committee members was initiated.  One committee member, plus the alternate were appointed to serve one-year terms, which ended January 2011.  The other two community members of the Board Audit Committee served two-year terms, which ended January 2012. 
	 
Through a general posting in the community, interested applicants were solicited to submit their applications.  The Board, at their meeting of March 13, 2012, took action to appoint Bruce Berg and Jon Reinke as members of the Board Audit Committee.
	 
The seat of alternate member was not filled.  As a result, the deadline to apply was extended thru May 1, 2012.  The District received one application for the vacant seat of Alternate Board Audit Committee Member.  For consideration and/or selection/appointment, the application submitted by Steffanee Taylor to serve as the Alternate Board Audit Committee Member is being submitted to the Board of Trustees.  Per the Audit Committee Charter, this vacant seat serves a term of one year, which will expire January 2013.
	 
	 
	 
	 
FISCAL IMPACT:
Not Applicable
	 
FUNDING SOURCE:
Not Applicable
	 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees consider the application of Steffanee Taylor as the selected/appointed alternate committee member to the Board Audit Committee.

EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
	 
Item:  11.05
				 
					 
TO:
Board of Trustees
					 
					 
FROM:  
Lan Nguyen, Board Member
					 
					 
PREPARED BY:
Juan Cruz, Assistant  Superintendent of Instructional Services, and Kirsten King, Director of Instructional Services
SUBJECT:
Discussion and/or Action regarding Partial Credit for Foster Youth
	 
The Board amended Board Policy #5120.1 on November 17, 2011, in compliance with AB 167.  Education Code 51225 and AB 167 provide alternative graduation requirements for students in foster care.  Students in foster care are forced to move to different schools and districts because of foster care placement issues.  In some cases, students move multiple times during a given school year.  As a result of these students changing schools midway through a semester, they oftentimes are not able to complete a full semester of coursework causing students to fall behind on graduation requirements.

Item:  11.06
	 
	 
TO:
Board of Trustees
				 
				 
FROM:  
Dan Moser, Superintendent
				 
				 
SUBJECT:
Receive and Adopt Second Reading of Proposed Amended Board Bylaw #9270 Conflict of Interest: Revolving Door Policy and #9270E (Appendix A) Designated Positions/Disclosure Categories - Dan Moser, Superintendent
	 
	 
Pursuant to the Government Code, the District is required to adopt a conflict of interest code.  The District's conflict of interest code is contained in Board By Law 9270.  The Government Code and the Rules and Regulations adopted by the Fair Political Practices Commission require the District to designate positions which are required to submit disclosures of financial interests, and to update the titles of positions when new positions are created, when position titles are changed, or when positions or position duties are revised or modified to fall within the disclosure categories.  The changes reflected in the attached draft proposed revised Board By Law 9270 and 9270E (Appendix A) clarify that the newly filled positions of Assistant Superintendent, District Architect and Project Manager are included within the category of positions required to submit disclosures.  
	 
	 
	 
FISCAL IMPACT:
Not Applicable
	 
FUNDING SOURCE:
Not Applicable
RECOMMENDATION:
The Board receive and adopt the second reading of the proposed amended Board By Law 9270 and 9270E (Appendix A) thereto as presented.

EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
	 
Item:  11.07
	 
	 
	 
	 
	 
TO:
Board of Trustees
				 
				 
FROM:  
Dan Moser, Superintendent
				 
				 
SUBJECT:
Receive and Adopt Second Reading of Proposed Amendments to Board Policy #2121 and Board Bylaws #9320 and #9321.1
	 
	 
Administration submits the attached proposed changes to Board Policy 2121 (Administration – Superintendent’s Contract) and Board Bylaws 9320 (Meetings and Notices) and 9321.1 (Closed Session Actions and Reports).  The proposed changes are intended to incorporate and address recent legislative changes regarding executive compensation and the new Brown Act requirement that agendas be posted on the district’s website (although that has been the district’s past practice, it was not required by law until very recently).  The new changes in the law are in Government Code section 54956 (requiring posting on the internet and prohibiting special meetings for the purpose of discussing or acting on executive compensation), Government Code section 54243-54243.4 (requiring that certain public agency executives pay back cash settlements in connection with termination if they are subsequently convicted of a crime involving an abuse of his or her office or position) and Government Code 3411.1-3411.2 (regulating the content of automatic renewal provisions in executive contracts).
	 
	 
	 
Fiscal Impact:
None
	 
Funding Source:
Not Applicable
	 
Recommendation:
Administration recommends that the Board receive and adopt the second reading of proposed amendments to Board Policy 2121 and Board Bylaws 9320 and 9321.1.

EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
	 
Item: 12.04
	 
TO:
Board of Trustees
					 
FROM:
Dan Moser, Superintendent
					 
					 
PREPARED BY:
Juan Cruz, Assistant Superintendent of Instructional Services, and George Sanchez, Coordinator of Student Services
					 
SUBJECT:
Adopt Santa Clara County Office of Education / East Side Union High School District’s Plan for Expelled Youth
					 
					 
As mandated by Education Code 48926, each county superintendent of schools in counties that operate community schools pursuant to Section 1980, in conjunction with superintendents of the school districts within the county, shall develop a plan for providing education services to all expelled students in that county.  The plan shall be adopted by the governing board of each school district within the county and by the county board of education.
					 
The plan shall enumerate existing education alternatives for expelled students, identify gaps in educational services to expelled students, and strategies for filling those service gaps.  The plan shall also identify alternative placements for students who are expelled and placed in district community day school programs, but who fail to meet the terms and conditions of their rehabilitation plan or who pose a danger to other district students, as determined by the governing board.
					 
Each county superintendent of schools, in conjunction with the superintendents of the school districts, shall submit to the Superintendent of Public Instruction the county plan for providing educational services to all expelled students in the county no later than June 30, 2012, and shall submit a triennial update to the plan to the Superintendent of Public Instruction, including the outcome data pursuant to Section 48916.1, on June 30th thereafter.
					 
Per Education Code 48916.1, at the time an expulsion of a student is ordered, the governing board of the school district shall ensure that an educational program is provided to the student who is subject to the expulsion order for the period of the expulsion.  Except for students expelled pursuant to subdivision (d) of Section 48915 (related to the five (5) offenses mandatory for recommendation of expulsion/to expel), the governing board is required to implement the provisions of this section only to the extent funds are appropriated for this purpose in the annual Budget Act or other legislation, or both.
					 
					 
					 
FISCAL IMPACT:
N/A
					 
FUNDING SOURCE:
N/A
					 
					 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees adopt the Santa Clara County Office of Education / East Side Union High School District’s Plan for Expelled Youth.

SUBJECT:                     Proposed Adoption of the Initial Proposal for Successor Contract: From East Side

The East Side Union High School District presents the following initial proposal to the California School Employees Association for the 2012-2013 school year.  Pursuant to Government Code §3547 the District’s initial proposal must be presented to the public in open session at a public meeting.
	 
The District continues to acknowledge and appreciate the contributions made to its mission and programs by its classified employees, and continues to seek the utilization of equitable and collaborative methods of addressing the needs of the students, parents and employees of the East Side Union High School District.  Accordingly, the District initially proposes to continue the language of the present agreement for the 
2012-2013 school year except as modified in a manner consistent with the matters and issues described below.
	 
The District continues to experience severe financial constraints arising from a variety of factors.  The District views financial issues in the context of keeping the District solvent, maintaining the legally required reserves, and preserving the quality education for the students of the District.  Given the above, the District proposes the following areas for negotiations: Adjustments/reductions in total compensation which includes salary and benefits; and reduction of work year.

Various

To be negotiated

EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
	 
Item:  13.03
	 
	 
TO:                               Board of Trustees
	 
FROM:                          Dan Moser, Superintendent
	 
PREPARED BY:           Cathy Giammona, Associate Superintendent, Human Resources and Instruction
	 
SUBJECT:                    Approve Declaration of Need for Fully Qualified Educators
	 
	 
In July 1994, the Commission on Teacher Credentialing changed the process for emergency credentialing.  Prior to that time, districts were required to issue individual statements of need for each applicant.  The applicant, in turn, would take the declaration of need to the county office of education for the issuance of an emergency credential. This applies to the following credentials or authorizations: Emergency CLAD, BCLAD, Resource Specialist, Library Media, Clinical or Rehabilitative Permits.
	 
Now, the Commission issues a permit to an individual who qualifies for an emergency based on the district’s Declaration of Need.  This Declaration, approved by the local Board of Trustees, is submitted to the Commission once a year.  
	 
Emergency permits, although originally used primarily to staff partial assignments and special education, now help fill the fully credentialed teacher gap created by class size reduction and statewide teacher shortage.  Every attempt is being made to hire credentialed teachers before considering people on emergency permits.  
	 
Attached is the Commission on Teacher Credentialing form titled Declaration of Need for Fully Qualified Educators.  Pursuant to direction from the county office of education’s credential’s office, the district is over estimating the number of permits it might require in order to cover any unanticipated needs that might occur during the course of the 2012-2013 school year.
	 
	 
FUNDING SOURCE:
As per salary schedule
	 
FISCAL IMPACT:
General, Special Education and Adult Education funds
	 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees approve the Declaration of Need for Fully Qualified Educators.

FROM:  
							 
Dan Moser, Superintendent
						 
						 
PREPARED BY:
Marcus Battle, Associate Superintendent of Business Services, and Karen Poon, Director of Finance
						 
						 
SUBJECT:
Presentation, Discussion and/or Action of Preliminary Budget 2012-13 
			 
			 
Attached for your review is a presentation of the 2012-13 Preliminary Budget as recommended. This is the first of three presentations of the budget to the Governing Board.  The preliminary budget is the result of a culmination of budget development activities between the sites, departments, and cabinet which provide a basis for the final budget.  The preliminary budget presentation is summarized first by providing an update on the District’s FYE 2011-12 budget, State budget update, and preliminary assumptions.  The FY 2011-12 budget is presented to provide year end projections for revenues, expenses, and ending fund balance. After reviewing the fiscal year end 2011-12 summary, major budget assumptions for developing the 2012-13 budget will be discussed including School Services of California dartboard, enrollment and ADA, and salaries and benefits.  The impact and adjustments based on the Governor’s May Revisions have not been announced yet and will be presented at the June 7th Board Meeting.  
			 
The preliminary budget presentation summarizes the projected estimate for general fund revenues and expenses for the budget year 2012-13 and for the multi-year thru 2014-15 and incorporates all proposed savings, additions and adjustments to the district’s budget.  The presentation concludes with a summary of proposed actions and next steps in the budget process.  The final budget will be presented for budget adoption at the June 21, 2012 Board meeting.  
			 
FISCAL IMPACT:
Not Applicable
			 
FUNDING SOURCE:
Not Applicable
			 
RECOMMENDATION:
Information Only

SUBJECT:
Approve Authorizing the First Amendment to the Solar Equipment Lease/Purchase Agreement, and Approving Related Documents and Actions
			 
			 
The District is recommending refinancing its obligation under the Solar Equipment Lease/Purchase Agreement dated July 30, 2010, between the Bank of America, N.A. and the District.  The refinancing of the loan will reduce the effective interest rate from 4.51% to 3.6%.  The refinancing of the agreement will lower the payments total amount due over the term of the loan by $305,000.00 dollars. If approved, no resolution would be necessary and the Board's action on this item would be sufficient to approve the transaction.
 
FISCAL IMPACT:
$305,000.00 savings over the term of the loan
			 
FUNDING SOURCE:
General Fund
			 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees approve the First Amendment to the Solar Equipment Lease/Purchase Agreement with Bank of America, in the principal amount of not to exceed $14,900,000.00 subject to district legal review and approving related documents and actions.

SUBJECT:

Attached is a list of warrants issued during the month of April 2012, in response to Board Policy 3314 Payment for Goods and Services adopted by the Board in May 2009.  The Policy states that, “The Board shall approve all warrants (checks) at a regularly scheduled Board meeting".  While there is no legal requirement for Board approval of issued warrants, this list and future lists will add to the “transparency” of when the Board approves purchase orders, contracts and other authorized expenses as per Board Policies.
